 The thing is, though, that if marriage is privatized people can have freedom without "redefining the standard." It is a way for us to allow all those oddball marriages without putting an "official stamp of approval" on them. 
 
 Liberals want to expand the government involvement in marriage to include gay marriages, thus putting society's approval on these things (something that gets moralists very angry.)
 
 Conservatives want to continue the statist rewards for straight marriage only - a violation of the 14th amendment.
 
 Libertarians combine the best of both positions. Their position (privatization) creates the freedom to marry, upholds the Constitution, and avoids official approval of gay marriage at the same time.

 I have to agree here with Bob. Civil Unions, as has been pointed out SEVERAL times, is no where near middle ground. They are not equal in regard to rights, priveledges or protections, nor are they federally recognized. 
 ONLY marriages for any persons wishing to do so, regardless of gender, is the true middle ground. 
 
 Here's a better analogy:
 
 Legally recognized marriage for intra racial, opposite gender couples ONLY
 .
 .
 .
 Legally recognized marriage for inter and intra racial, opposite gendered couples only
 .
 .
 .
 Legally recognized marriage for inter and intra racial, same or opposite gendered couples 
 .
 .
 .
 Legally recognized marriage for inter and intra racial, same and opposite gender multiple partnered "groups" 
 .
 .
 .
 No legally recognized marriage for any couples or groups at all.
 
 Still, in the middle is a volutary, COUPLES only, legally recognized MARRIAGE for same and/or opposite genders. 
 This still allowed for the rights, protections and priveledges enjoyed by those already married opposite gender couples, while including same gender couples as well. It does not include multiple partnered groups, nor does it remove the rights, priveledges or protections from those who already have such. 
 
 It's not a "free for all" at all. It's still only two individuals entering into the legally recognized contract of marriage.
